definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To get back , to regain (a physical thing; in astronomy and navigation, sight of a thing or a signal).
examples: After days of inquiries, he finally recovered his lost wallet.
For days telescopes surveyed the skies to recover the small asteroid.

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To salvage , to extricate , to rescue (a thing or person).
examples: They recovered three of the explorers very much alive, then another, wracked with severe hypothermia, who was taken to hospital.

definitions.definition: ( transitive ) To replenish to, resume (a good state of mind or body).
examples: At the top of the hill I asked to stop for a few minutes to recover my strength.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive , law ) To obtain a positive judgement; to win in a lawsuit.
examples: The plaintiff recovered in his suit, being awarded declaratory relief and a clearing of his name.

definitions.definition: ( transitive , law ) To gain as compensation or reparation, usually by formal legal process.
examples: to recover damages in trespass; to recover debt and costs in a legal action or that is owing
to recover lands in ejectment or common recovery

definitions.definition: ( transitive , obsolete ) To reach (a place), arrive at.
( transitive , archaic ) To restore to good health, consciousness, life etc.
( transitive , archaic ) To make good by reparation; to make up for; to retrieve; to repair the loss or injury of.
( intransitive ) To regain one's composure, balance etc.
examples: Spinning round, he caught a stone with his ankle, but recovered quickly before turning to face me.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive , followed by "from" to show what caused the bad feeling ) To get better , to regain health or prosperity.
examples: I was hurt, but I knew I’d recover , given time.
Without calling in Business Recovery experts, the company saw trade and investor confidence recover sharply in the wake of the crisis.
I lost out in the deal, but I quickly recovered financially
It takes time and good health to recover from injury, surgery, a bereavement and emotional turmoil

definitions.definition: ( transitive , archaic , without "from" ) To recover from.
examples: To the end of his days, he never fully recovered his daughter's death.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To get back , to regain (a physical thing; in astronomy and navigation, sight of a thing or a signal).

definitions.definition: To add a new roof membrane or steep-slope covering over an existing one.

secondary_definitions: ( roofing ) To add a new roof membrane or steep-slope covering over an existing one.
